subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: ... Close, except I don t make the mistake you ve (purposefully) made here, including the multiple test with the oneLineItem test. My test class in this
messageBody:
On Wed, 5 Jan 2005 11:20:48 -0700, Mike Clark <mike@...> wrote:
> I try to arrange my test case classes around common text fixtures. One
> side effect of doing that is it gives me an extra layer of context (a
> namespace) on top of the test method name. So, given my limited
> knowledge of your problem domain, I might have a test case like this:
>
> public class OneSalesOrderLineTest extends TestCase {
>
> public void setUp() {
> // fixture for one sales order line
> }
>
> public void testCreateMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntries() {
> }
>
> public void testSomethingElseAboutOneSalesOrderLine() {
> }
> }

Close, except I don't make the mistake you've (purposefully) made
here, including the 'multiple' test with the 'oneLineItem' test.

My test class in this case is called something like
"SpecificClientMappingSupportTest" where 'SpecificClient' is the name
of one of our clients who has a bit of byzantine business logic that
must be supported by our system. The tests all rely on fixtures that
configure the system to understand that it's reading data for this
client, and that create inputs that resemble those that would come
from other parts of the system for this client.

So, like you, I'm reading the tests in this class, and I know I'm in
the context of the StarbucksMapperSupport (Starbucks is not the real
name, just a name I can see from my window).

> > This particular example is partly about readability (you could infer a
> > lot of the information, possibly, from the method name) and part about
> > disambiguity. There are other tests involving CustomerPurchaseOrders
> > and Sales Order Lines that are similar.
>
> Does using a separate test case help with the ambiguity?

I'm not sure what you mean here. I'm trying to disambiguate this
testcase with another testCase that is named similarly:

testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForManySalesOrderLinesWithDuplicates();

That test too has commentary describing the situation. That one has a
bug# as well, apparently I did it wrong at one point in time.

>
> > Most of the time, these comments are written before the test. I guess
> > you could say I practice document-first test development. I write a
> > sentence or two about what the test is going to do (or just a method
> > name if it suffices -- you're right that it often does) then I write
> > the test.
>
> I often use that technique, as well. By writing out prose, I find
> words that I'd like to use in the test method name.

True, and most often I do the same thing. But there are cases where I
felt that the prose held more information than the method name I came
up with. I'd already written the prose, so I left it to guide me in
the implementation, and describe the situation to the maintainers.

>
> > Ultimately, why wouldn't you want to write actual sentences? I like
> > Java a lot, but English was my first language.
>
> I'm not saying you should never write sentences. However, if I can
> convey the same meaning in a method name, I'll do that instead of
> maintaining two separate pieces of information (the sentence and the
> method name).

I think folks are overstating my intentions a bit: I'm *not* saying
that *all* tests need javadoc documentation, I'm not even saying that
most of them do. The only point I'm making is that occasionally you
need it, and not shipping the javadoc (the original question) makes
that occasional-but-important information unavailable to whoever is
using the unit tests.

-Kevin Klinemeier
